ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: If looking to get credit for a business in the early stages of start-up, this class may be beneficial. However, if you have prior experience in the start up space, the first half of the course offers few new lessons.
Although there is a lot of work to do for this class, I appreciate that Maureen and David works just as hard in preparing for it.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Learning about other people's projects is cool but you don't hear about them a lot until the end. A debrief in the middle would be nice to know how everyone else is struggling/their strategies, etc.
Coaching, providing connections, tough love.
The team coaching sessions.
Gives you the opportunity to work on a project you're passionate about for course credit, and you get tons of feedback from two willing professors on your venture.
Team work, research and innovative problem-solving
The assignments for this class are where the bulk of the learning happens.
The coaching on the business plan is so very helpful. Also, the professors are willing to help in many ways with preparing your plan for competitions. They are a valuable resource.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Lectures are not always super valuable (could be even online?) but the coaching and assignments are great.

Some of the lectures do not seem that valuable. A handout on do's and don'ts of business writing would be a little more respectful of all of our time than an evening lecture. Also can be very repetitive. Flip side though is that I will never use hype ever in any business writing I ever do.

I wonder if it might be slightly out dated. It seems this class has been taught the same way for 20 years. Is this still what VCs are looking for? Also, it's VC heavy. There are other funding platforms that might be more suited to our type of ventures. We should learn a bit about impact investing ect.
The logistics of individual meetings with Maureen and David. Meeting in a classroom can be distracting. They should reserve breaking rooms at SOM.
Lectures become repetitive quickly.
The lectures get a little bit redundant and could use some spicing up.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Fine.
It was very appropriate and effective.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I want to be an entrepreneur. This course is a must take if that is what you want to do.
I am interested in sustainability and entrepreneurship in urban areas and this class and the business we are advancing is perfectly aligned with those.
I'm interested in social entrepreneurship, and this class is helping me to get an idea of what it would take to actually start a business.
I am interested in learning about starting ventures.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: entrepreneurship is really exciting and I want to start my own company someday.
See answer to 17 and 14
To make an idea of sustainability into a profitable reality. To become part of the entrepreneurship ecosystem in South America.
I wanted to learn how to start a business and potentially get our idea off the ground.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes, very much so. Doing market research and thinking about customers was very helpful.
So far. I really look forward to the second half of the course for some more "hard" business skills.

The course is only half over, but I think I've definitely gotten a better idea of what investors are looking for in a business plan. I don't feel like an expert, but hopefully I'll have a good grounding by the end of the course.
Yes
Yes.
The practical skills are invaluable and have really helped improve my work on business planning and also in my other courses.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Tricky to work with so many people. But it really shows who is taking what load on and it's a good lesson in leadership.
Group work is essential, really challenging, and really rewarding.

Lots of people to do lots of work. It's nice to split it up and to have people helping with my venture. The downside is that they have varying levels of understanding about the venture, and I feel like I often have to go over there work and occasionally re-do it.
Practicing my ability to delegate and be efficient with time managamenet
Group work always presents its own challenges, but the point of this course is to practice working in a group as one inevitably would do if starting a business.

This is a team-based course and you really need to have a strong team in order to have any success in this course. There is a mountain of research and editing required that you simply could not achieve alone, with a full course-load, in a single semester.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take this course if you have any interest at all in entrepreneurship!
From the beginning firmly establish what everyone wants out of the project and the class, how real the project is to them and what they want to contribute.
Do it. Make sure it's with a group you like working with and a project you're passionate about though.
Pick your group based on the people who you can trust to do a good job and have your back.
You get out what you put in. If you're willing to spend time and energy on the assignments, you'll learn a lot. If not, you won't learn much and it's probably not worth taking.
Listen to the coaching and work hard. You can only get advice on the work that you complete and show to the professors so make the most of that opportunity.
